Base:Descriptions.Base:Description: the main hall of Doloreaux Manor

The main hall of Doloreaux Manor. A vast room stretches out before you, two stories high. Nearly everything in this area is constructed from stone. Elaborate obsidian and sandstone carvings set with a myriad of gems, decorate the walls. A heavy marble balcony, supported by enormous green marble columns, spans the length of the southern wall, complete with a scalloped obsidian balustrade. The otherwise cold, dark brown marble flooring has been covered with a soft velvet pile area rug in the center of the room, adding a measure of warmth to the space. Even the walls in the room are detailed with meticulously carved reliefs upon their shiny surfaces. There is an elaborate green marble arch to the north, a light carved sugar maple door to the east, a glossy beech door to the south, the grand black obsidian archway to the west, a pair of beech double doors to the northwest, and a ceiling high double door to the southwest which you cannot enter unless you are on the balcony.

The main hall of Doloreaux Manor. There is an elaborate green marble arch to the north, a light carved sugar maple door to the east, a glossy beech door to the south, the grand black obsidian archway to the west, a pair of beech double doors to the northwest, and a ceiling high double door to the southwest which you cannot enter unless you are on the balcony.

The main hall of Doloreaux Manor. A vast, two story hall stretches out before you. Nearly every wall in this area has been decorated with carved reliefs upon their inlaid surfaces. A balcony, supported by enormous columns, spans along the length of the southern wall. There is an elaborate green marble arch to the north, a light carved sugar maple door to the east, a glossy beech door to the south, the grand black obsidian archway to the west, a pair of beech double doors to the northwest, and a ceiling high double door to the southwest which you cannot enter unless you are on the balcony.
http://wp.skotos.net/ironclaw/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/maps/Mini_Maps/NewTown_South/Manors/Doloreaux/dolo-main.jpg

An elaborate green marble arch, complete with ivory insets. Trails of climbing vines surround this structure in natural beauty. At a glance:

a grand black obsidian archway

A grand black obsidian archway, complete with ivory insets. Trails of climbing vines surround this structure in natural beauty. This archway can boast of three small steps that lead up to it.
At a glance:

A grand black obsidian archway.
At a glance:
obsidian Bruges landscape carving

Inlaid into the green-veined sandstone is brilliantly decorated obsidian depicting an exquisitely detailed view of the Rothos Mountains. Large clouds heavily lined with ivory seemingly thrust off the wall giving passage to the quartz-capped snowy mountaintops. To the right, a topaz stream trickles down into a full body of lapis lazuli which has been meticulously shaped into a massive lake. Overwhelmingly intricate, these carvings are a timeless masterpiece.
Inlaid into the green-veined sandstone of the eastern wall is brilliantly carved obsidian. At a glance, you can only discern the exquisitely detailed depiction of the Rothos Mountains.
green-veined sandstone butterfly carving

Inlaid into the sleek obsidian which decorates the upper ten feet of the east wall is magnificently carved green-veined sandstone. It has been etched vertically and outlined in peridot to create a stunning stem. A large yellow foxglove bursts forth from its body, the golden bell-shaped blooms dangling downward in a pose of reverence. Mandarin garnets sparkle the inside of the flowers while thin streaks of bloodstone insets comprise the stamen. Hovering just to the right is an impressively designed painted lady butterfly. Lustrous orange beryl with spatters of brilliant zircon decorate the majority of her wings as small ivory spots give way to the obsidian eastern wall, providing for a mottled appearance.

Inlaid into the sleek obsidian which decorates the upper ten feet of the east wall is magnificently carved green-veined sandstone. At a glance, you can only discern the golden hues of a flower and an object hovering nearby.
obsidian sky carving

Inlaid into the green-veined sandstone of the northern wall is ornately carved obsidian depicting a sky scene such as you've never observed. The northern wall is artistically divided in the middle, half of it decorated in pure obsidian with a series of multi-faceted gold stars that almost seem to dance within, cavorting and shifting magnificently until they flare to a nova brilliance and then taper gradually toward the left edge of the wall into gold spackles. The other portion of the sky is like a bottle of colored sands, continuously shaken: belts of fire opals, zircons, garnets, sapphires, agates, and amethysts turn and twist; patches of emeralds, mauve pearls, moonstones, and diamonds come into play from the right creating impossible perceptions of distance and nearness. At times, some or all seem literally sky-high, then again they fill the wall before you as gauzy, transparent mists, translucent swaths, or solid tentacles of color. The line which separates the black from the color has been created to give the illusion of advancing slowly toward the right while retreating toward the left. It is as if the entire celestial mandala is rotating about a common point.
Inlaid into the green-veined sandstone of the northern wall is ornately carved obsidian. At a glance, you can only discern the image of a sky.
obsidian floral carving

Inlaid into the green-veined sandstone of the southern wall is masterfully decorated obsidian depicting a common teasel. Puckered chrysoprase leaves are fused around a flowering jade stem forming a cup that has collected sapphire rainwater from the dark obsidian clouds overhead. The jade stem branches at the top as cone-shaped flower clusters form at the ends of the branches. Below each cluster and curving upward around it are several stiff bracts. Many short bristles within these clusters are cleverly interspersed with individual flowers consisting of diamond petals united into a tube with four amethyst lobes.
Inlaid into the green-veined sandstone of the southern wall is masterfully carved obsidian. At a glance, you can only discern a prickly object resembling a flower.
green-veined sandstone unicorn carving

Inlaid into the sleek obsidian which decorates the upper ten feet of the southern wall is luxuriously carved green-veined sandstone. Glinting diamonds outline and create the image of a unicorn, it's body and mane detailed with insets of soft, shimmering ivory. It's tiny, cloven hooves are etched in gold, as is the delicate, whorled horn that rises from it's narrow head. It stands atop a lesser rock, nibbling at the jade lichen that grows there like wildflowers. It's emerald eyes gaze directly at you, piercingly bright and intensely detailed. It appears to be making a nervous gesture with it's front feet, pawing the air and striking stone. The carving becomes somewhat blurred in the middle, as if to represent movement, and then vanishes, giving way to the green-veined sandstone woods.
Inlaid into the sleek obsidian which decorates the upper ten feet of the southern wall is luxuriously carved green-veined sandstone. At a glance, you can only discern the glint of diamonds.
obsidian castle carving

Inlaid into the green-veined sandstone of the western wall is brilliantly decorated obsidian depicting a grandiose view of Bruges Castle. Billowing clouds delicately crafted in moonstone hang in the background giving passage to the distant Rothos mountaintops which have been etched with fine insets of hematite. To the right and left, a lush forest detailed in emerald and jade vibrantly surrounds the outskirts of the structure. The Castle itself has been meticulously created with diamonds, its many towers, spires, and windows capped with extravagant cuts of sapphire. The heavily outlined gates are decorated with amber and appear to be open, lending an inviting atmosphere to the picturesque scene.
Inlaid into the green-veined sandstone of the western wall is brilliantly carved obsidian. At a glance, you can only discern the green hues of vegetation and a few rising towers.
green-veined sandstone bird carving

Inlaid into the sleek obsidian which decorates the upper ten feet of the west wall is beautifully carved green-veined sandstone. It has been etched into a dense forest creating a lively backdrop for the goshawk which seems to swoop off the wall toward the balcony. It is outlined in agate, its downy feathers detailed with rich insets of white and brown jasper. Its underparts are barred with obsidian, as is its broad tail which has been brought to life with smoky moonstones. Wide diamond-laced supercilia and piercing sunstone eyes make this creature almost evil-looking. The cere is decorated in citrine, its legs and feet comprised entirely of chrysoberyl. The right eye of this particular bird has been surrounded in circular waves of onyx lending to an even more fearsome appearance.
Inlaid into the sleek obsidian which decorates the upper ten feet of the west wall is beautifully carved green-veined sandstone. At a glance, you can only discern the body of a bird mid-swoop.
the ceiling

A high arched ceiling made of thick, polished beech wood. Evenly-spaced beech buttresses extend from the upper portions of the walls to support the high ceiling, forming an intricate criss-cross network above your head. In the middle of each buttress, a two-dimensional scene is carved in which the apparition of a woman appears to a daydreamer who is staring off into space.

A high arched ceiling made of thick, polished beech wood. Evenly-spaced buttresses extend from the upper portions of the walls to support the high ceiling. In the middle of each buttress, a two-dimensional scene is carved in which the apparition of a woman appears to a daydreamer who is staring off into space.
marble column

One of the four white-veined green marble columns that support the balcony. It stands approximately twenty feet high. It consists of a simple rounded base, a broad fluted shaft, and a capital sculpted with an overlapping leaf design.
One of four white-veined green marble columns supporting the balcony. The capital is sculpted to give the appearance of overlapping leaves.
marble column

One of the four white-veined green marble columns that support the balcony. It stands approximately twenty feet high. It consists of a simple rounded base, a broad fluted shaft, and a capital sculpted with an overlapping leaf design.
One of four white-veined green marble columns supporting the balcony. The capital is sculpted to give the appearance of overlapping leaves.
marble column

One of the four white-veined green marble columns that support the balcony. It stands approximately twenty feet high. It consists of a simple rounded base, a broad fluted shaft, and a capital sculpted with an overlapping leaf design.
One of four white-veined green marble columns supporting the balcony. The capital is sculpted to give the appearance of overlapping leaves.
marble column

One of the four white-veined green marble columns that support the balcony. It stands approximately twenty feet high. It consists of a simple rounded base, a broad fluted shaft, and a capital sculpted with an overlapping leaf design.
One of four white-veined green marble columns supporting the balcony. The capital is sculpted to give the appearance of overlapping leaves.
the floor
The floor is made from beautiful dark brown marble which has been evenly laid to create a completely solid surface beneath your feet.
The floor is made from beautiful dark brown marble.
some climbing ivy
The large expanse of live climbing ivy grows entwined around the individual balusters of the balcony railing, twisting this way and that in a beautiful mass of green curves, spirals, and leaves.
The large expanse of live climbing ivy grows entwined around the individual balusters of the balcony railing.
stone pillar railing of the balcony
The stone pillar railing of the balcony wraps around the entirety of the balcony to keep people from falling over.
The stone pillar railing of the balcony wraps around the entirety of the balcony.
thickly-woven area rug

A thickly-woven area rug covers the floor in the center of the room. It boasts a neutral field of faint green ferns and a border of wildflowers which are framed by an edging of spritely vegetation in deep, earthy greens and mauves. With its soft pile, this rug adds lovely definition to the main hall.
A thickly-woven area rug covers the floor in the center of the room with an mass of woven flowers as the border around a field of faint green ferns at the center..
the eastern wall

The first twenty feet of the eastern wall is made up of impressive green-veined sandstone and has been inlaid with brilliantly carved obsidian. At the base of the balcony, the upper ten feet contrasts strikingly bearing the opposite appearance of a sleek obsidian construct with magnificent inlays of carved, green-veined sandstone. Evenly-spaced beech buttresses extend from the upper portions of the walls to support the high ceiling, forming an intricate criss-cross network above your head.

The first twenty feet of the eastern wall is made up of impressive green-veined sandstone and has been inlaid with brilliantly carved obsidian. At the base of the balcony, the upper ten feet contrasts strikingly bearing the opposite appearance of a sleek obsidian construct with magnificent inlays of carved, green-veined sandstone. Beech buttresses extend from the upper portions of the walls to support the high ceiling overhead.
the northern wall

The northern wall is made up of impressive green-veined sandstone and has been inlaid with brilliantly carved obsidian. Evenly-spaced beech buttresses extend from the upper portions of the walls to support the high ceiling, forming an intricate criss-cross network above your head.

The northern wall is made up of impressive green-veined sandstone and has been inlaid with brilliantly carved obsidian. It ends at the base of the balcony. Beech buttresses extend from the upper portions of the walls to support the high ceiling overhead.

Evenly-spaced beech buttresses extend from the upper portions of the walls to support the high ceiling, forming an intricate criss-cross network above your head.

Beech buttresses extend from the upper portions of the walls to support the high ceiling overhead.
